title: Introduction to Investing
description: Master the fundamentals of investing and build a strong foundation for your financial journey.
objectives: Understand what investing is and why it matters
Learn different types of investments and their characteristics
Master the concept of risk and return relationship
Understand the power of compounding over time
Learn diversification and asset allocation strategies

lessons.title: What is Investing?

content.original: Investing is the process of allocating money with the expectation of generating returns over time. Unlike saving, which focuses on preserving capital, investing aims to grow wealth through appreciation, dividends, or interest. The fundamental principle is that money today is worth more than the same amount in the future due to inflation and opportunity cost.
content.simplified: Investing means putting your money to work so it grows over time. It's different from just saving money in a bank. When you invest, you buy things like stocks or bonds that can increase in value and earn you more money.

lessons.title: Types of Investments

content.original: Investment vehicles include stocks (equity ownership), bonds (debt instruments), mutual funds (pooled investments), ETFs (exchange-traded funds), real estate, commodities, and alternative investments. Each asset class has distinct risk-return profiles, liquidity characteristics, and tax implications.
content.simplified: There are many ways to invest: stocks (own part of a company), bonds (lend money to companies/government), mutual funds (professionals invest for you), real estate (property), and gold. Each has different risks and rewards.

keyTakeaways: Each asset class serves different goals
commonMistakes: Putting all money in one type of investment

lessons.title: Risk and Return Relationship

content.original: The risk-return tradeoff is fundamental: higher potential returns come with higher risk. Risk encompasses market risk, credit risk, liquidity risk, and inflation risk. Return includes capital gains, dividends, and interest. Risk tolerance varies by age, financial goals, and personal circumstances.
content.simplified: Higher returns usually mean higher risk. If someone promises guaranteed high returns, be careful - it might be a scam. Your age and goals determine how much risk you should take. Young investors can take more risk.

keyTakeaways: Never invest in what you don't understand
commonMistakes: Chasing high returns without assessing risk
Not matching investments to risk tolerance

lessons.title: Power of Compounding

content.original: Compound interest is earning returns on your returns. Einstein called it the 'eighth wonder of the world'. The formula: A = P(1 + r/n)^(nt). Starting early dramatically amplifies wealth accumulation due to exponential growth over time.
content.simplified: Compounding means your money earns money, and then that earned money also earns money. Example: â‚¹10,000 at 10% yearly becomes â‚¹25,937 in 10 years without adding anything. Start early to get huge benefits.

lessons.title: Diversification and Asset Allocation

content.original: Diversification spreads risk across multiple assets, sectors, and geographies. The principle: don't put all eggs in one basket. Asset allocation determines 90% of portfolio returns. Rebalancing maintains desired risk levels. Age-based allocation: 100 minus age in equity.
content.simplified: Diversification means spreading your money across different investments. If one fails, others protect you. Mix stocks, bonds, gold based on your age and goals. Don't invest everything in one company or sector. Younger people can invest more in stocks.
